title: R40482
content: The Department of State, Foreign Operations, and Related Programs appropriations legislation (SFOPS) funds nondefense international affairs activities. Congress divides SFOPS into titles and paragraphs that address component accounts. In the FY2019 Consolidated Appropriations Act, SFOPS is divided into eight titles. The Appropriations Act (Division F) is divided into eight titles, each associated with various activities. Title 22 of the U.S. Code contains many statutory authorities, including the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956, the Foreign Service Act of 1980, and the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. This report identifies the statutory authorities enabling each component account to function, with a list of major acts and their location in the U.S. Code provided in Appendix A. For more information on SFOPS funding levels and congressional action, refer to CRS Report R45168. The FY2019 Budget and Appropriations program funds State Department personnel, operations, international organizations, nonmilitary broadcasting, and U.S. nongovernmental agencies. The Administration of Foreign Affairs account category supports State Department personnel, operations, diplomatic security, and facility maintenance worldwide. The Administration of Foreign Affairs account category funds State Department personnel, operations, diplomatic security, and facility maintenance worldwide. Funding categories include Human Resources, Overseas Programs, and Diplomatic Policy and Support, which cover salaries, training services, operating costs, diversity recruitment programs, regional bureaus, foreign policy programs, strategic and managerial units, and various bureaus within the Department. The Security Programs account funds security programs and policies within the State Department, including those for counterterrorism and protecting staff, property, and information. It also supports the Worldwide Security Protection subaccount for Diplomatic Security. Starting in FY2019, consular fees and surcharges were redirected to a new Consular and Border Security Programs account. The CBSP account, established in 1994, funds IT procurement and supports the State Department's IT modernization initiative. It also funds the Office of Inspector General for audits and investigations, as well as U.S. educational and cultural exchanges. The Fulbright Scholar Program, International Visitor Leadership Program, and Congress-Bundestag Youth Exchange are funded by the Mutual Education and Cultural Exchange Act of 1961. The Representation Expenses account reimburses Foreign Service Officers for entertaining government officials to advance diplomacy. ESCM funds are used for managing and maintaining U.S. State Department embassies and facilities worldwide, including renovations to the State Department headquarters. The account funds renovations to the State Department headquarters in Washington, DC, Worldwide Security Upgrades for new embassies, and facilities. It also covers costs for unexpected events like evacuations due to natural disasters, terrorist attacks, or civil unrest. Additionally, it funds nonemergency activities of senior Administration officials and rewards for informants on international terrorism. The "Rewards for Justice" program gathers information on international terrorism, narcotics-related activities, organized crime, and war crimes. It has led to the capture of a planner of the 1993 World Trade Center bombing. The Repatriation Loans Program Account provides small loans to destitute U.S. citizens abroad. AIT is a nonprofit corporation that provides consular services for Americans and Taiwan under the Taiwan Relations Act. The International Center, or the International Chancery Center (ICC), is a diplomatic enclave in Washington, DC funded by fees from executive agencies and past leases. It was established by Congress to provide territory for foreign diplomatic missions. The U.S. government pays for salaries, benefits, and expenses associated with maintaining AIT through the International Center Act. The payment also covers contributions to retirement and pension systems for USAID and the Department of State. The United States meets its obligations to international organizations and peacekeeping efforts through two accounts in the International Organizations category. Title V of SFOPS appropriates voluntary contributions to multilateral organizations, including U.S.-assessed contributions to the budget of the United Nations, inter-American organizations, war crimes tribunals, and other intergovernmental organizations. The Contributions for International Peacekeeping Activities account funds U.S.-assessed contributions to U.N. peacekeeping operations worldwide and certain ad hoc courts. International Commissions category provides funding for U.S. obligations under law or treaty to bilateral and multilateral commissions. The International Commissions category provides funding for U.S. obligations to bilateral and multilateral commissions, including the International Joint Commission, International Boundary Commission, International Boundary and Water Commission, and Border Environment Cooperation Commission. The BBG is the U.S. civilian international media agency, comprising Voice of America, Radio and TV Martí, Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, Radio Free Asia, and Alhurra TV and Radio Sawa. The Broadcasting Board of Governors (BBG) funds operations for various international broadcasts including Liberty (RFE/RL), Radio Free Asia (RFA), and Alhurra TV and Radio Sawa. Programmatic expansion priorities in FY2019 include new Russian and Korean language programs, increased focus on Venezuela, and a digital media program in the Middle East and North Africa to counter extremist narratives. Capital Improvements account supports maintenance of BBG's global transmission network and digital multimedia infrastructure. Funding also goes to entities aligned with U.S. foreign policy objectives. The Asia Foundation and the U.S. Institute of Peace receive funding from various sources including the U.S. government, foreign governments, nonprofits, corporations, competitive grants, and individual contributions. They work to strengthen democratic institutions, counter violent extremism, promote economic opportunities, and improve U.S.-Asian relations. USIP was established in 1984 to prevent and resolve international conflicts without violence. The United States Institute of Peace (USIP) was established in 1984 by Congress to provide training, analysis, and resources for peacebuilding efforts. It is funded solely by the U.S. government and focuses on conflict prevention and resolution. The International Center for Middle Eastern-Western Dialogue, also known as the Hollings Center, promotes dialogue between the U.S. and Muslim-majority nations. The Eisenhower Exchange Program brings rising leaders from various countries to the U.S. for career development opportunities. The IASP funds scholarships for Israeli Arabs to attend higher education in the US, while the East-West Center in Hawaii promotes better relations in the Asia-Pacific region. NED fosters democratic institutions abroad. The National Endowment for Democracy (NED) was established in 1983 to support various organizations, including four core institutes: the National Democratic Institute (NDI), the International Republican Institute (IRI), the Center for International Private Enterprise, and the Solidarity Center. NED receives funding from the Democracy Fund and works to promote election-related capacity building, strengthen democratic institutions, support the private sector, and advocate for labor rights abroad. The Commission for the Preservation of America's Heritage Abroad, an independent executive agency established in 1998, identifies and protects cemeteries, monuments, and historic buildings in Eastern and Central Europe associated with the heritage of U.S. citizens, particularly American Jews. It works with the Department of State to ensure the preservation of these properties and promotes international religious freedom. The Commission for the Preservation of America's Heritage Abroad, established in 1998, protects cemeteries, monuments, and historic buildings in Eastern and Central Europe related to the heritage of U.S. citizens, especially American Jews. It collaborates with the State Department to ensure preservation and promote international religious freedom. Additionally, the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE) was established in 1975 to monitor and promote human rights, military security, and economic cooperation in the 57-country Organization on Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE). The Congressional-Executive Commission on China (CECC) monitors human rights and the rule of law in China, providing annual reports and recommendations to Congress on national security implications. The Commission for the Preservation of America's Heritage Abroad protects cemeteries, monuments, and historic buildings in Eastern and Central Europe related to the heritage of U.S. citizens. It collaborates with the State Department to ensure preservation and promote international religious freedom. The Operational Expenses (OE) account funds USAID's overseas and domestic operational expenses, including salaries, benefits, mission activities, staff training, and security. The CIF supports USAID's information technology modernization and overseas facility construction. It also funds operational costs for the Office of the Inspector General and other agencies supporting U.S. foreign policy objectives worldwide. The Global Health Programs (GHP) account supports various health activities worldwide, including combating infectious diseases like HIV/AIDS, malaria, and tuberculosis. Managed by USAID and the State Department, funds are used for programs on immunization, maternal and child health, family planning, and the President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). Additionally, funds from this account support the U.S. contribution to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS. The Development Assistance account, managed by USAID, funds programs aligned with priorities in the FAA, including agriculture, education, energy, urban development, disaster preparedness, and micro-enterprise development. It also supports environment, democracy, governance, water, sanitation, and human rights programs. In sub-Saharan Africa, the Development Assistance account funds priorities such as agricultural production, natural resources, health, family planning, education, and income-generating activities. Managed by USAID, it provides relief and rehabilitation to nations affected by disasters. The account has been increasingly used for emergency food aid, with half of funding in 2017 going towards this compared to less than 5% in 2010. The Transition Initiatives account supports USAID's Office of Transition Initiatives activities. The Office of Transition Initiatives (OTI) was established in 1994 by USAID to support short-term projects in countries transitioning from conflict to peace. It focuses on addressing political factors to promote peaceful and democratic societies, differentiating itself from the International Disaster Assistance (IDA) which focuses on humanitarian needs. OTI aims to prevent violence by addressing root causes of conflict and instability. The Development Credit Authority (DCA) is administered by USAID under the FAA, providing flexible funding for housing projects, water systems, and small enterprise development. It allows transfers from DA, GHP, and Assistance for Europe, Eurasia, and Central Asia for loan guarantees. The BUILD Act of 2018 further supports DCA's mission. The BUILD Act merges the Development Credit Authority (DCA) into a new United States International Development Finance Corporation. The Economic Support Fund (ESF) uses economic assistance to advance U.S. political and strategic goals in countries important to U.S. foreign policy, supporting a range of development projects and providing direct budget support aid and sovereign loan guarantees. The Economic Support Fund (ESF) is used for direct budget support aid and sovereign loan guarantees, overseen by the State Department's Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor (DRL). Funding since FY2017 goes exclusively to DRL for democracy promotion programs in former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The Democracy Fund was added in 2002 to provide economic assistance to these regions, succeeding two earlier accounts. AEECA was discontinued between FY2013 and FY2015 at the Obama Administration's request. The AEECA program was discontinued between FY2013 and FY2015 at the Obama Administration's request but reinstated in FY2016. It is funded through various accounts such as ESF, GHP, and INCLE. The Migration and Refugee Assistance account supports refugee assistance worldwide, including contributions to organizations like UNHCR and IOM. The Migration and Refugee Assistance Act of 1962 (P.L. 87-510) authorizes the placement of refugees in the United States. ERMA is a fund for refugee emergencies, replenished by appropriations and requiring notification to Congress when funds are used. The Peace Corps promotes mutual understanding through volunteer work, while the MCC provides development grants to foreign governments. The Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) provides development grants to foreign governments through bilateral agreements known as "compacts" to promote economic growth and eliminate extreme poverty. The Inter-American Foundation (IAF) and the U.S. African Development Foundation (USADF) are nonprofit corporations that finance small-scale enterprise and grassroots community self-help activities for social and economic development in Latin America. The African Development Foundation Act was established in 1980 to support economic reforms in developing countries, focusing on banking, financial institutions, financial crimes, government debt, revenue policy, and financial accountability. The INCLE program funds counternarcotics, human and wildlife trafficking combat, and rule of law activities, overseen by the State Department's Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs. The INCLE program, funded by the FAA, supports activities such as countering weapons proliferation, antiterrorism training, demining operations, and voluntary contributions to nonproliferation-focused international organizations. It also provides defense articles related to nonproliferation, demining, and antiterrorism to friendly governments, as well as supports disarmament in the former Soviet Union. The PKO account provides voluntary support for multilateral conflict resolution efforts, focusing on the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa. The State Department controls the funds and sets program policies, while DOD implements the activities. Through IMET, the U.S. provides training on military practices and democratic values to foreign personnel. The Foreign Military Financing Program supports U.S. overseas arms transfers on a loan and grant basis, with funds controlled by the State Department and implemented by the Department of Defense. Funding is used by recipient countries to purchase U.S. weapons, equipment, and training, with a portion allocated to Israel for purchases from Israeli defense firms. Additionally, the account provides voluntary State Department-administered U.S. donations supporting international agencies involved in development, humanitarian, and scientific activities. The U.N. Development Program (UNDP), U.N. Environment Program (UNEP), U.N. Children's Fund (UNICEF), and U.N. Population Fund (UNFPA) receive funds through the Department of the Treasury for loans and grants to developing countries and private sector entities. Some international financial institutions receive U.S. contributions through multiyear "replenishments." Contributions for concessional lending or grant-making are authorized in appropriations acts of the relevant year. In FY2019, U.S. appropriations funded entities like the Global Environment Facility (GEF), International Development Association (IDA), and Asian Development Fund (AsDF) for grants and concessional loans to developing countries. The Asian Development Bank (AsDB) ceased issuing concessional loans in 2017 and now finances them directly through its capital reserves. The African Development Bank (AfDB) lends at near-market rates with a focus on agriculture, infrastructure, and industrial development. The AfDF, part of the AfDB, provides concessional loans and grants to low-income African countries. The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) issues grants and low-interest loans to improve rural incomes and food security. The Export-Import Bank of the United States (Ex-Im Bank) supports U.S. exports through direct loans, loan guarantees, and export credit insurance. The Export-Import Bank of the United States (Ex-Im Bank) provides credit insurance to support U.S. exports of goods and services, aiming to support U.S. jobs by providing financing when the private sector is unable to do so alone. The bank's program expenses are financed by collections like loan interest and fees, with congressional appropriations setting a ceiling. The Office of Inspector General also receives an appropriation. Ex-Im Bank's enabling legislation is the Export-Import Bank Act of 1945. OPIC offers political risk insurance, guarantees, and investment financing to encourage U.S. firms to invest in developing countries under the authority of the FAA. The agency funds itself with loan receipts, with appropriations setting ceilings on administrative expenses for insurance programs. The BUILD Act authorizes the new U.S. International Development Finance Corporation (IDFC) to absorb OPIC and USAID responsibilities, adding new authorities. The FAA section will be repealed after IDFC is operational, terminating OPIC. TDA funds project preparation services for U.S. businesses in emerging markets. General Provisions set limitations on assistance, administrative requirements, and funding for specific accounts. Title VII of the legislation outlines detailed funding requirements for various aid sectors, including education, democracy promotion, water and sanitation, and food security. It also specifies aid allocations for certain countries and regions. Since FY2012, there has been a distinction between "core" international affairs funding and funding for "overseas contingency operations" (OCO), which initially focused on Afghanistan, Iraq, and Pakistan but later expanded to include other activities and countries. OCO funds do not count towards spending caps. OCO funds are used to maintain international affairs funding levels without exceeding budget restraints. The Trump Administration proposed eliminating OCO funding for FY2019 and FY2020, but Congress continues to designate it in legislation. OCO funding supports accounts in Titles I-V separately identified in Title VIII.
